unnormalised: Mumbai's Crawford Market saw vegetable prices soar this week. Tomato prices, typically around Rs. 40 per kg, jumped to Rs. 80/kg due to unseasonal rains disrupting supply chains from Nashik. Traders report a similar trend with onions, rising from Rs. 25 to ₹45 a kilo.
normalised: Mumbai's Crawford Market saw vegetable prices soar this week. Tomato prices, typically around rupees forty per kilogram, jumped to rupees eighty per kilogram due to unseasonal rains disrupting supply chains from Nashik. Traders report a similar trend with onions, rising from rupees twenty five to rupees forty five a kilo.

unnormalised: Retail prices in local areas reflect these increases. A survey in Dadar showed consumers paying ₹90 for 1 kg of tomatoes, while smaller vendors are charging even more, with some quoting Rs 100/kg. This surge impacts household budgets, especially for daily wage earners who rely on affordable vegetables.
normalised: Retail prices in local areas reflect these increases. A survey in Dadar showed consumers paying rupees ninety for one kilogram of tomatoes, while smaller vendors are charging even more, with some quoting rupees one hundred per kilogram. This surge impacts household budgets, especially for daily wage earners who rely on affordable vegetables.

unnormalised: Experts attribute the volatility to several factors. Besides the rainfall, increased transportation costs and hoarding contribute to inflated prices. The government’s efforts to control prices through subsidies haven't fully alleviated the situation, impacting consumer spending by approximately 15%, according to local economists.
normalised: Experts attribute the volatility to several factors. Besides the rainfall, increased transportation costs and hoarding contribute to inflated prices. The government’s efforts to control prices through subsidies haven't fully alleviated the situation, impacting consumer spending by approximately fifteen percent, according to local economists.

unnormalised: The wholesale price index for vegetables has climbed by 12% in the last week alone. While some anticipate prices will normalize in the next 2-3 weeks as supplies stabilize, retailers warn consumers to expect higher costs in the short term, suggesting planning meals around seasonal produce.
normalised: The wholesale price index for vegetables has climbed by twelve percent in the last week alone. While some anticipate prices will normalize in the next two to three weeks as supplies stabilize, retailers warn consumers to expect higher costs in the short term, suggesting planning meals around seasonal produce.

unnormalised: The agricultural ministry recommends consumers explore alternative vegetables to mitigate the impact. Also, consumers should be vigilant against vendors charging above the MRP or maximum retail price. Consumer forums encourage reporting price discrepancies via helpline number 1800-11-4000.
